questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents to the clinic with a high fever, severe muscle aches, and a headache that has persisted for three days. She has recently travelled to a dengue-endemic region. Which of the following symptoms is NOT considered a warning sign in dengue for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Dengue Case Classification based on the severity (WHO 2009)
 

Criteria for Dengue ± Warning Signs

Criteria for Severe Dengue

Probable dengue

Live in/travel to dengue endemic area.

Fever and two of the following criteria:

  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Rash
  • Aches and pains
  • Tourniquet test positive
  • Leukopenia
  • Any warning sign
 

Laboratory-confirmed dengue

(important when no sign of plasma leakage)

Warning signs*

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness (Option A ruled out)
  • Persistent vomiting (Option B ruled out)
  • Clinical fluid accumulation
  • Mucosal bleed
  • Lethargy, restlessness
  • Liver enlargement >2 cm (Option D ruled out)
  • Laboratory: increase in HCT concurrent with rapid decrease in platelet count
 

*Requiring strict observation and medical intervention
  1. Severe plasma leakage leading to:
  • Shock (Dengue shock syndrome)
  • Fluid accumulation with respiratory distress
  1. Severe bleeding
  • As evaluated by the clinician (causing hemodynamic instability and may require a blood transfusion)
  1. Severe organ involvement
  • Liver: AST or ALT ≥1000 IU/mL
  • CNS: Impaired consciousness
  • Heart and other organs

questions.text: Which of the following findings would be most indicative of HTLV-1-associated adult T-cell leukaemia (ATL)?

options.label: A
options.text: High levels of interleukin-2 receptors in peripheral blood

options.label: B
options.text: Detection of p24 antigen in serum

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of CD4+ T cells in the peripheral blood

options.label: D
options.text: Detection of GLUT1 on the surface of leukemic cells

questions.correct_answer: A. High levels of interleukin-2 receptors in peripheral blood

questions.text: A 30 y/o man presents to the clinic with flu-like symptoms 12 days after potential exposure to HIV. The clinician suspects acute HIV infection and orders a diagnostic test. Which test would be most appropriate to confirm the infection at this early stage and provide insights into the viral load?

A 32-year-old woman receives a positive HIV screening test result. To confirm the diagnosis, the healthcare provider decides to use a supplemental test for validation due to its high specificity in detecting individual antibodies against various HIV antigens. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis in this case?

A 34 y/o patient with recent high-risk exposure tests positive for HIV-1 antibodies and negative for HIV-2 antibodies on an HIV-1/HIV-2 differentiation immunoassay. The initial fourth-generation antigen/antibody immunoassay had also shown positive results for HIV-1. What is the next step in confirming the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Order a Western Blot to confirm HIV-1 antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an HIV-1 NAT (Nucleic Acid Test)

options.label: D
options.text: No further testing is needed; confirm HIV-1 infection

questions.correct_answer: D. No further testing is needed; confirm HIV-1 infection

questions.text: A 40 y/o HIV-positive patient who used to weigh 80kg, now weighs only 64kg and reports experiencing chronic diarrhoea for the last 5 weeks and a persistent fever that has lasted over a month. He has no other signs or symptoms. According to the WHO AIDS case definition, which of the following most accurately describes his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient does not meet the criteria for AIDS diagnosis.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient meets the criteria for AIDS diagnosis based on major signs only.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient meets the criteria for AIDS diagnosis based on minor signs only.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient meets the criteria for AIDS diagnosis based on both major and minor signs.

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient meets the criteria for AIDS diagnosis based on major signs only.
questions.explanation:
Major signs (2 signs or more)

Minor signs (1 or more)
  • Weight loss of at least 10% of body weight
  • Chronic diarrhoea for >1 month
  • Prolonged fever for >1 month (intermittent or constant)
  • Persistent cough for >1 month
  • Generalized pruritic dermatitis
  • History of herpes zoster
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Chronic progressive or disseminated herpes virus infection
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Match the following opportunistic infections with their respective CD4 counts Cerebral toxoplasmosis a) <50 Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia b) <200 Kaposi sarcoma c) <100 Mycobacterium avian complex (MAC) d) <500
questions.explanation:
CD4 count

Opportunistic Infection

<500

Tuberculosis, Bacterial pneumonia, Herpes zoster, oropharyngeal candidiasis, non-Typhoid Salmonellosis, Kaposi sarcoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

<200

Pneumocystis Jiroveci Pneumonia, Herpes Simplex Ulcer, Oesophogeal Candidiasis, Isospora Bell diarrhoea, HIV wasting syndrome, HIV-associated dementia.

<100

Cerebral Toxoplasmosis, Cryptococcal meningitis, Cryptosporidiosis, Microsporidiosis, CMV, MAC, PMLE

<50

CMV, MAC, Toxoplasma gondi

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman visits the clinic with complaints of swollen lymph nodes in her neck and armpits. She reports that these have been present for the past four months, but she feels generally well otherwise. A laboratory evaluation shows no other significant findings. Based on this information, which of the following CDC Classifications is the most appropriate for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Group

Description

Group I

Acute infection

  • Defined by a mononucleosis-like syndrome with seroconversion for antibodies. (Option A ruled out)
  • Antibody seroconversion is essential; viral isolation methods lack sensitivity.

Group II

Asymptomatic infection

  • No signs or symptoms of infection; no prior classification in Groups III or IV. (Option B ruled out)
  • Laboratory evaluations, including blood counts, are key for subclassification.

Group III

Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

  • Palpable lymphadenopathy (≥1 cm) at two or more extra-inguinal sites for over 3 months. (Option C)
  • Laboratory evaluations can subclassify patients.

Group IV

Other disease

  • Classified into subgroups (A-E) independent of lymphadenopathy presence. (Option D ruled out)
  • Includes a range of symptoms, with potential for further specificity in subgroups.

Subgroup A

Constitutional disease

Subgroup B

Neurologic disease

Subgroup C

Secondary infectious diseases

Category C-1

Specified secondary infectious diseases listed in the CDC surveillance definition for AIDS**

Category C-2

Other specified secondary infectious diseases

Subgroup D

Secondary cancers**

Subgroup E

Other conditions

questions.text: A 40 y/o man presents to the clinic after having unprotected sex with multiple partners. He is concerned about his risk of contracting HIV and asks how the virus enters the body and its modes of transmission. Which of the following statements regarding HIV transmission and pathogenesis is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The least common mode of HIV transmission is through perinatal transmission.

options.label: B
options.text: HIV binds its gp41 to the CD4 receptor on host cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Viral load is the least in saliva and CSF.

options.label: D
options.text: The CCR5 Delta 32 mutation can confer resistance to HIV in homozygous individuals.

questions.correct_answer: D. The CCR5 Delta 32 mutation can confer resistance to HIV in homozygous individuals.

questions.text: Identify and group the structural (a) and non-structural (b) genes of HIV from the given: Gag Vpr Tat Pol Env Nef Vif
questions.explanation:
Structural Genes (3)

Non-structural Genes (6)
  1. gag Gene: Codes for the virus's core and shell components. The precursor protein p55 is cleaved into:
  • p18: Matrix or shell antigen.
  • p24 and p15: Core antigens.

Essential Regulatory Genes:

  • tat: Transcriptional transactivator. Tat recruits cellular transcription factors to the HIV-1 promoter.
  • nef: Negative factor. Regulatory protein that affects HIV-1 virulence
  • rev: Regulator of virus gene. The HIV-1 Rev protein regulates post-transcriptional processing of viral mRNAs
  1. pol Gene: Codes for viral enzymes, including reverse transcriptase, protease, and integrase. It is expressed as a precursor protein that is cleaved into:
  • p31: Integrase.
  • p51 and p66: Reverse transcriptase.

Accessory Regulatory Genes:

  • vif: Viral infectivity factor.
  • vpr: Involved in viral replication.
  • vpu: Enhances the maturation and release of progeny virus from cells.
  1. env Gene: Codes for the envelope glycoprotein gp160, which is cleaved into:
  • gp120: Main receptor that binds to CD4 on host cells, initiating infection.
  • gp41: Fusion protein facilitating entry into the host cell.

questions.text: A 35 y/o man visits the clinic after testing positive for HIV. He is concerned about the type of virus he may have and how it affects his treatment options. The clinician explains the structure of HIV and its classification into different serotypes. Which of the following statements regarding the structure and serotyping of HIV is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: HIV has an envelope with glycoproteins gp120 and gp41.

options.label: B
options.text: HIV-1 is classified into groups M, N, O, and P, with group M being the most dominant.

options.label: C
options.text: The capsid has an complex symmetry and contains core proteins.

options.label: D
options.text: HIV-2 has eight subtypes, mainly found in Africa, with Group A being the most common.

questions.correct_answer: C. The capsid has an complex symmetry and contains core proteins.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a high fever, severe headache, and joint pain for the past 4 days. O/E, he has mild abdominal tenderness, and his laboratory results show leukopenia. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to confirm his diagnosis at this stage of his illness?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ NS1 Antigen Detection: Detectable from day 1 of fever up to 18 days; specific to dengue and differentiates flaviviruses.
  • ↳ NS1 Antigen Detection:
  • ↳ Antibody Detection: IgM (Primary Infection): Appears after 5 days; MAC-ELISA is the recommended test. IgG (Secondary Infection): Rapid rise; may cross-react with other flaviviruses.
  • ↳ Antibody Detection:
  • ↳ IgM (Primary Infection): Appears after 5 days; MAC-ELISA is the recommended test. IgG (Secondary Infection): Rapid rise; may cross-react with other flaviviruses.
  • ↳ IgM (Primary Infection): Appears after 5 days; MAC-ELISA is the recommended test.
  • ↳ IgM (Primary Infection):
  • ↳ MAC-ELISA
  • ↳ IgG (Secondary Infection): Rapid rise; may cross-react with other flaviviruses.
  • ↳ IgG (Secondary Infection):
  • ↳ Neutralization Tests: Plaque reduction and microneutralization tests; specific but complex, mostly used in research.
  • ↳ Neutralization Tests:
  • ↳ Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs): Detects IgM or NS1 antigen but has limited sensitivity; ELISA confirmation is required for a positive result.
  • ↳ Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs):
  • ↳ ELISA
  • ↳ Virus Isolation: Virus detectable in blood up to 5 days post-symptoms; performed in research/reference centres.
  • ↳ Virus Isolation:
  • ↳ Molecular Methods (RT-PCR): Detects viral RNA from day -1 to +5; is highly sensitive and specific, and also helps in serotyping.
  • ↳ Molecular Methods (RT-PCR):
  • ↳ Treatment:
  • ↳ Treatment:
  • ↳ There is no specific antiviral therapy; supportive care includes plasma replacement, correction of electrolyte imbalances, and platelet transfusions as needed. Outpatient Management (no warning signs): Administer acetaminophen. Encourage sufficient oral fluid intake. Inpatient Management (with warning signs or severe dengue): Initiate IV crystalloids; adjust the fluid rate based on patient response. For shock not responding to crystalloid boluses, consider colloids. Blood Transfusion: Indicated in cases of severe or suspected bleeding if unstable despite fluid resuscitation and hematocrit falls. Consider platelet transfusion if the platelet count is below 20,000 cells/µL with high bleeding risk.
  • ↳ There is no specific antiviral therapy; supportive care includes plasma replacement, correction of electrolyte imbalances, and platelet transfusions as needed.
  • ↳ Outpatient Management (no warning signs): Administer acetaminophen. Encourage sufficient oral fluid intake.
  • ↳ Outpatient Management (no warning signs):
  • ↳ Administer acetaminophen. Encourage sufficient oral fluid intake.
  • ↳ Administer acetaminophen.
  • ↳ Encourage sufficient oral fluid intake.
  • ↳ Inpatient Management (with warning signs or severe dengue): Initiate IV crystalloids; adjust the fluid rate based on patient response. For shock not responding to crystalloid boluses, consider colloids.
  • ↳ Inpatient Management (with warning signs or severe dengue):
  • ↳ Initiate IV crystalloids; adjust the fluid rate based on patient response. For shock not responding to crystalloid boluses, consider colloids.
  • ↳ Initiate IV crystalloids; adjust the fluid rate based on patient response.
  • ↳ For shock not responding to crystalloid boluses, consider colloids.
  • ↳ Blood Transfusion: Indicated in cases of severe or suspected bleeding if unstable despite fluid resuscitation and hematocrit falls. Consider platelet transfusion if the platelet count is below 20,000 cells/µL with high bleeding risk.
  • ↳ Blood Transfusion:
  • ↳ Indicated in cases of severe or suspected bleeding if unstable despite fluid resuscitation and hematocrit falls. Consider platelet transfusion if the platelet count is below 20,000 cells/µL with high bleeding risk.
  • ↳ Indicated in cases of severe or suspected bleeding if unstable despite fluid resuscitation and hematocrit falls.
  • ↳ Consider platelet transfusion if the platelet count is below 20,000 cells/µL with high bleeding risk.
  • ↳ Vaccine (CYD-TDV - Dengvaxia):
  • ↳ Vaccine (CYD-TDV - Dengvaxia):
  • ↳ Live-attenuated, tetravalent vaccine; indicated for ages 9-45 with prior dengue infection. Administered in 3 doses over six months; effective (~80%) in reducing hospitalized cases in high-prevalence regions. WHO advises use only in previously infected individuals due to potential risks for severe dengue in dengue-naive recipients.
  • ↳ Live-attenuated, tetravalent vaccine; indicated for ages 9-45 with prior dengue infection.
  • ↳ Administered in 3 doses over six months; effective (~80%) in reducing hospitalized cases in high-prevalence regions.
  • ↳ WHO advises use only in previously infected individuals due to potential risks for severe dengue in dengue-naive recipients.
  • ↳ IgG Antibody Detection (Option B): IgG antibodies indicate a secondary infection and appear later than the NS1 antigen. This test would not be suitable for early diagnosis in this acute phase of illness.
  • ↳ IgG Antibody Detection (Option B):
  • ↳ Virus Isolation (Option C): While virus isolation can confirm dengue infection, it is generally performed in specialized research centres and is not practical for immediate diagnosis in clinical settings.
  • ↳ Virus Isolation (Option C):
  • ↳ Rapid Diagnostic Test (Option D): Although RDTs can detect IgM or NS1 antigen, they have limited sensitivity and require confirmation with ELISA. Therefore, they are less reliable for initial diagnosis compared to NS1 antigen detection
  • ↳ Rapid Diagnostic Test (Option D):

questions.text: A 30 y/o farmer from Central Asia presents with high fever, muscle pain, and significant bleeding from his gums and nose. He mentions being bitten by a tick while working on his farm. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Bunyaviridae
  • Bunyaviridae is a large family of over 300 arbovirus species, mostly spread by mosquitoes and ticks.
  • Structure: Virions are spherical, enveloped, and are about 100 nm in size. They have a segmented, single-stranded RNA genome.
  • Key Genera: Four genera are medically significant—Bunyavirus, Phlebovirus, Nairovirus, and Hantavirus. Hantaviruses are rodent-borne rather than transmitted by arthropods.

Name

Features

Transmission

Genus Bunyavirus
  • Encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, and fever.
  • California encephalitis viruses are endemic to the USA.
  • Oropouche virus causes fever with aseptic meningitis in Brazil.

California encephalitis virus - Mosquito

Oropouche virus - Midges

Genus Phlebovirus

Causes sandfly fever (Pappataci fever) in Central Asia and Rift Valley fever in Africa.

Fever and myalgia

Sandfly fever - Phlebotomus papatasii sandflies

Rift Valley fever - Mosquitoes (Option B ruled out)

Genus Nairovirus (Option C)

Nairobi sheep disease virus and Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF).

CCHF - Hyalomma ticks

Genus Hantavirus

Causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS).

Hantaan virus: Severe HFRS in Asia and Russia. (Option D ruled out)

Seoul virus: Worldwide mild disease

Puumala virus: Mild nephropathia in Europe.

Sin Nombre virus: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. (Option A ruled out)

Rodents

questions.text: A 26-y/o patient presents with fever, headache, muscle and joint pains, and maculopapular rashes over the chest and upper limbs for five days. The patient reports lymphadenopathy, retro-orbital pain, and loss of appetite. Lab results show haemoglobin at 10 g/dL, WBC count of 10,000 cells/mm³, platelet count of 15,000 cells/mm³, and prolonged bleeding time with normal clotting time. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 26 y/o pregnant woman is concerned about Zika virus exposure after returning from Brazil, where she experienced mild fever and rash. What infant complication is associated with the Zika virus?

A 27-y/o employee from the forest department presents with high fever, malaise, and frontal headaches, followed by bleeding from the nasal cavity, throat, gums and hematemesis. Recently, he worked in a forest area in Karnataka that has a significant population of monkeys. What is the vector responsible for the disease?
questions.explanation:
Vector

Diseases transmitted

Sandfly (Option A ruled out)

Kala-azar

Oriental sore

Sandfly fever (Papatasi fever)

Flea (Option C ruled out)

Hymenolepis diminuta

Hymenolepis nana

Bubonic plague

Endemic typhus

Louse (Option D ruled out)

Epidemic relapsing fever

Epidemic typhus

Trench fever

Hard tick

Babesiosis

Kyasanur Forest disease virus (Option B)

Colorado tick fever virus

Russian spring-summer encephalitis virus

Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever virus

Tularemia

Lyme disease

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Indian tick typhus

Ehrlichiosis

Soft tick

Endemic relapsing fever

Reduvid bug

Chagas’ disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old male returns from South America and presents to the ED with severe abdominal pain, jaundice, and bleeding manifestations. O/E his liver is enlarged, and lab tests show elevated liver enzymes. Despite receiving medical care, he did not survive. An autopsy shows the presence of intranuclear Torre bodies in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis, and which vaccine could have prevented it?

A 35-y/o male presents with fever, chills, headache, dizziness, myalgia, and backache, followed by nausea and vomiting. O/E hemorrhagic manifestations, thrombocytopenia, jaundice, relative bradycardia and elevated creatinine levels are seen. Histopathology findings show mid-zonal necrosis with Councilman bodies in the liver. What is the vector responsible for transmitting the disease?
Which of the following vaccines is included in India’s National Immunization Program to prevent Japanese encephalitis in children?

A 12-year-old girl from Bihar presents with high fever, confusion, and seizures. Her family reports she frequently plays near rice fields. O/E there is nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the primary amplifier host in the transmission cycle of the suspected infection?
questions.explanation:
Japanese Encephalitis Virus

Vector

Clinical features

  • Culex mosquitoes, particularly Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India).
  • Breeding Habitats: These mosquitoes thrive in rice fields and stagnant water, especially in rural regions.

 
  • Incubation Period: Typically 5-15 days.
  • Many infections are asymptomatic or subclinical.
  • Stages of Disease:
    • Prodromal Stage: Initial fever and flu-like symptoms.
    • Acute Encephalitis Stage: High fever, neurological symptoms (confusion, seizures, stiff neck).
    • Late Stage and Sequelae: Potential for full recovery or long-term neurological complications.
  • Age Distribution: Primarily affects children under 15, significantly impacting young children.
  • Geographical Distribution: Endemic across South East Asia

questions.text: What laboratory test would be most helpful in confirming a diagnosis of an active rubella infection in a pregnant patient?

A 6 y/o boy presents to the clinic with a rash that started on his face and spread to his trunk and limbs. His mother reports that he has been experiencing mild fever and has developed swollen lymph nodes behind his ears. What additional finding would most likely support a diagnosis of rubella?

A 58-year-old woman presents with fever, severe joint pain in the wrist and ankle, and a faint rash. She reports mosquito bites over the past week while visiting a tropical region. Given these symptoms and recent exposure history, which test result would most likely confirm the suspected viral infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Detection of IgG antibodies in the first week

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of IgM antibodies in serum in the first two days

options.label: C
options.text: Detection of viral RNA by RT-PCR

options.label: D
options.text: Positive blood culture for chikungunya virus

questions.correct_answer: C. Detection of viral RNA by RT-PCR
questions.explanation:
Chikungunya virus

Vector

Clinical Manifestation

Diagnosis
  • Chikungunya virus belongs to A the Togaviridae family.
  • Transmitted by Aedes aegypti, which are day-biting insects often found in human dwellings.
  • Incubation Period: Around 5 (3–7) days.
  • High fever and severe joint pain (arthralgia) causing a stooped posture.
  • Other symptoms: headache, muscle pain, skin rashes, and tenosynovitis.
  • Joint pain is intense, affecting small joints like wrists and ankles and it can persist for months.
  • Viral Isolation: Viruses can be isolated from mosquito cell lines, but are only done in specialized labs.
  • Serum Antibodies:
    • IgM antibodies: Appear around 4 days after infection, lasting up to 3 months. (Option B ruled out)
    • IgG antibodies: Detected after 2 weeks and persist for years, significant when there is a fourfold rise. (Option A ruled out)
  • Molecular Diagnosis: RT-PCR is effective for detecting viral RNA. (Option C)
